Problem:
Consider the behaviour of the complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t} \\), where \\( \\omega \in \mathbb{R} \\), under the Laplace Transform \\( \mathcal{L} \\). Analyze how transformations affect causality in the complex function mapping and their implications on the frequency domain.

If an intervention by scaling \\( z(t) \\) with a factor \\( e^{\\alpha t} \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant, is applied at a time \\( t_0 \\), will the Laplace Transform output at any \\( s \\) solely depend on the original frequency \\( \\omega \\) regardless of \\( \\alpha \\)?
Explanation: Scaling \\( z(t) \\) with \\( e^{\\alpha t} \\) alters the function to \\( e^{(\\alpha+i\\omega) t} \\). The Laplace Transform of this new function, \\( \mathcal{L}[z](s) = \\frac{1}{s-(\\alpha+i\\omega)} \\), clearly depends on both \\( \\alpha \\) and \\( \\omega \\). Thus, the output at any \\( s \\) will reflect contributions from both the scaling intervention and the original frequency.
